Title: University Band to Welcome Visitors
Item Description: The sixty members of the band will be on hand in full uniform to greet Vice President (General) Dawes and General Pershing when they arrive. Nineteen of the band members are new this semester, and they have a busy week ahead of them.

People: Pershing, John J. (John Joseph); Dawes, Charles G.
Title: Pershing and Dawes to Talk at Convocation
Item Description: R.O.T.C. members will be excused from classes in order to greet General Dawes at the Northwestern station. Multiple bands and groups will be part of a reception party for the Vice President and General. There will be a parade from the Northwestern station down 9th St to O, then east to 14th, then north to the Coliseum. High schools taking part include parochial, teachers' college, Lincoln, University Place, Bethany, and College View.

Subjects: Events & Dances; Parade; Military; Sports; Concert
Title: Reception for U.S. Navy Band Being Planned
Item Description: Lieutenant Charles Benter and the United States Navy Band will give a concert at the Coliseum. The R.O.T.C. band will meet them at the Rock Island Train depot in the morning and parade from Q to 16th, then south to O, then to 9th street, then to the Lincoln Hotel. Lt. Benter has volunteered to lead the R.O.T.C. band and cheer section at the freshman football game, as the Navy band may only perform in official concerts.

Subjects: Events & Dances; Parade; Military; Sports; Concert
Title: State Bankers Arrange Dance for Students
Item Description: The State Bankers' Convention is sponsoring a dance at the Coliseum on Thursday, at which the university band will perform. Earlier in the day, the R.O.T.C. will give a parade.

Subjects: Cheer & Pep; Parade; Military; Events & Dances; Other Band
Title: Students Take Part in Parade
Item Description: The band and R.O.T.C. units participated in the Armistice Day parade, which began at 17th and O. A large crowd gathered to see the parade, sometimes pushing into the street. Boy Scouts, the Lincoln High School Band, and 1,500 school children, and the Women's Athletic Association took part in the parade as well, along with the cadet regiment sponsors.

Title: Homecoming Grid Rally is Tonight
Item Description: There are multiple rallies planned in advance of the "Kansas Aggie" game to celebrate Homecoming. The band will perform in front of Social Sciences between classes.

Title: Band Benefit is Saturday
Item Description: The Band Benefit party will be held in the Coliseum to raise funds for the band's trip to Seattle. It is hoped that 1,200 couples may attend. Band members will be performing much of the musical entertainment.

Title: Send the Band
Item Description: Leon D. Larimer writes an opinion, which urges students to purchase tickets to attend the R.O.T.C. band benefit dance. The proceeds of this event will fund the band's travel to Washington.

Title: Double Rally Will be Held Friday Night
Item Description: The band will lead a torchlight parade from the Armory to the Lincoln Hotel. The rally will be for two football games, one for the game against New York the following day, and another to send the football team to Washington, as they will be departing on Saturday after the game.

Title: Band Benefit Dance Planned
Item Description: Tickets are now being sold for the Band benefit dance, which will fund the band's travel to Seattle. Fraternities are encouraged to sell tickets to support the band. Band director Quick notes that since there will not be a large cheering section for the football team on the west coast, sending the band would do "all that is possible in the way of giving the team moral support."

Subjects: Parade; Travel; Cheer & Pep; Drill; Pregame & Halftime
Title: Stunts, Rallies, and Parades Are Among Duties of R. O. T. C. Band
Item Description: The R.O.T.C. band has had a busy semester after playing at every football game of the season save one away game. Additionally, band members also take part in weekly radio broadcasts, rallies, parades, and non-university events. The band recently traveled to Washington. This article describes some of the halftime programs, broadcasts, and the insufficient amount of uniforms for all band members.

Title: Largest Rally of the Season is Arranged
Item Description: The band will be part of a rally before the Syracuse game for a football game dubbed "Dads' Day." Students are encouraged to bring their fathers to witness the rally and the game. There will be a parade from the Coliseum to the Lincoln Hotel.

Title: Nebraskans to Stage Annual Bonfire Rally
Item Description: There is a rally and bonfire planned in advance of the Homecoming game against Kansas. Freshmen are asked to bring a box which will be stacked and lit at the rally. The band will perform at the rally.

Title: Freshmen Asked to Bring Boxes for Bonfire Rally
Item Description: The freshmen are asked to take part in a bonfire on Friday night. On Saturday, the band will lead a parade through Lincoln to the football field.

Title: Band Launches Campaign for New York Trip
Item Description: The band is hosting a Band Ball to fundraise for a trip to West Point. Ben Simons and Sons will print 5,000 tickets free of charge.

Title: Friday Night Rally Will Greet Visitors
Item Description: The band will take part in a rally at the Coliseum in advance of the Syracuse game. "Dads will be present" proclaims the article, reminding students that this is Dad's Day.

Title: Band and R.O.T.C. Officers Appointed
Item Description: Willard Rollin Barnes is the new band captain, other officers also appointed.

Subjects: Events & Dances; Other Band; Fundraising & Finance
Title: Missouri Band is Engaged for R. O. T. C. Dance
Item Description: Herb Fick and his Missouri Quadrangle will perform at the R.O.T.C. Band Ball in the Coliseum for Homecoming. The band will be selling tickets city-wide to fundraise to West Point.

Title: Huge Rally Will Welcome Syracuse
Item Description: The band will lead a parade from the Coliseum to the Lincoln Hotel to welcome Syracuse to Lincoln. Many fathers will be on hand for the Dad's Day game. Several small rallies will be held on Friday morning.

Title: Today is the Day
Item Description: The band will perform ten minute rallies between classes in advance of the football game against Missouri.

Subjects: Events & Dances; Travel; Fundraising & Finance; Other Band
Title: Students Will Find it Hard 'To Beat The Band'
Item Description: The Band Ball will take place following the Missouri game. Students and fans of both Nebraska and Missouri will enjoy entertainment by Herb Fick's Missouri Quadrangle orchestra. Proceeds from the dance will fund the band's travel to West Point.

Title: Band Ball Tickets are Moving Slowly
Item Description: The band requires $4,500 to $5,000 in proceeds from the Band Ball if they hope to travel to West Point. The Band Ball will take place on Homecoming Saturday following the game, not on Friday.

Subjects: Fundraising & Finance; Events & Dances; Other Band; Travel
Title: Business Men Send Band Ball Ticket Sale Up
Item Description: Red Long of the College Bookstore has purchased 50 tickets to the Band Ball to support the band's travel to West Point. Lincoln businesses are largely repsonsible for Band Ball tickets. Herb Fick's Missouri Quadrangle Collegians have been booked for the musical entertainment.

Title: Big Rally Dance with Herb Fick
Item Description: Herb Fick and his Quadrangle Orchestra will be performing at the Lincoln Hotel on Friday, a day before they perform at the Band Ball.

Title: Are You Ready for the Tumultous Tomorrow?
Item Description: An advertisement in the paper from Ben Simon & Sons (a Lincoln business which printed Band Ball tickets for free) greets Missouri fans and graduates returning for Homecoming. The advertisement encourages all to "send the band to West Point" by attending the Band Ball. Additionally, to make sure that you are well dressed for the weather, the advertisement encourages you to get a Four Winds Topcoat.

Title: Band Ball Nets Less Than Third Amount Needed
Item Description: The Band Ball brought in $1,500 which is unfortunately short of the amount needed to send the band to West Point. The band will be traveling to Lawrence, Kansas this weekend.

Title: Husker Special Leaves Lincoln Friday Morning
Item Description: 80 members of the band will travel to Kansas on the Union Pacific along with the football team.

Title: Special Train Takes Gridiron Party East
Item Description: The band is on its way to West Point. The article lays out the schedule of rallies, drill, and sightseeing.

Title: Huge Send-Off Rally Starts Team to Army
Item Description: The band leads a rally before The Cornhusker Special carries the football team and band to New York for the West Point game. The band led a parade from the Social Sciences building through downtown to the train station. Fifty members of the band will travel.

Title: New Rifle Gallery is Open in Andrews
Item Description: This article mentions that Colonel Jewett is en route to West Point with the band and will not be available for fall shooting practice.

Title: Radio Broadcast is Boost to Band Fund
Item Description: The R.O.T.C. Band performed on KFAB, station of the Nebraska Buick company, to fundraise for the West Point Trip. They received $596.00 through their efforts. Donors are listed on page 3.

Title: Gigantic Rally is Planned for Team Send-Off
Item Description: The band will lead a rally and parade from the Social Sciences building to the Burlington train depot. The band hopes to accompany the football team to West Point for the Army game.

Title: Feather Sales Give Impetus to Campaign
Item Description: Sales of feathers during the Pittsburgh game the previous Saturday have put the band closer to their goal of financing their trip to West Point. The amount raised has not yet been counted.

People: Ayres, W. Joyce; Quick, W. T.
Title: Band Men Are Picked for West Point Trip
Item Description: Fifty members of the R.O.T.C. band will travel to West Point. $4,600 was raised towards the trip, and the band members attending will each pay $10. The train leaves at 4:30 pm the following day. The names of the band members are listed in the article.

Title: Band of Fifty Will Make Trip to West Point
Item Description: Fifty members of the R.O.T.C. bnad will travel to West Point after $4,500 was raised for their expenses. This amount was reached after considerable effort through fundraising such as the Band Ball, selling of "N" feathers by the Corn Cobs, buckets in the stadium, radio programs, and contributions from organizations and individuals. Gen. John J. Pershing donated $25 towards the band's trip. The band will lead a parade to the Burlington Station before departing.

Title: Last Send-Off Rally Will Be for Army Game
Item Description: The band will lead a parade from campus do to O street, then to 9th Street, then to the train depot. Students are asked not to drive cars in the parade.

Title: And the Band Goes
Item Description: After fundraising $4,500 towards their trip, the band will be traveling to West Point for the Army game. "Gratitude expressed would be indeed profuse if every individual who worked to send the band on the eastern trip received thanks."

Title: [Untitled]
Item Description: Text of opinion: "Looks like a dull weekend ahead with both team and band in the East. The campus has been more interested in Far East aid than in Near East relief lately."

Title: Innocents Set Last Rally of Year for Today
Item Description: The band will perform at the final rally of the year in advance of the Iowa State football game.

Title: Cornhusker,' Written by Professor Stevens of Music School, Fought Hard to Obtain Recognition on Campus
Item Description: This article describes the history of "The Cornhusker" song written by Professor Stevens. It first began as a quartet performed by glee club at a football game. Despite a cold reception initially, "The Cornhusker" began to catch on in the absence of any of fight songs of note.

Title: Local News [Grant]
Item Description: The cadets are traveling to Omaha for General Grant's reception.

Title: Local News [Grant]
Item Description: The cadets escort General Grant in Omaha and "performed their evolutions more skilfully than any of the malitia [militia] companies that participated in the reception."

Title: Locals [Band Concerts]
Item Description: Text reads: "The University Cadet Band will soon give open-air concerts. The boys are improving rapidly in their practice and by Commencement, no doubt, will be quite proficient. They have been engaged to discourse sweet music at Palladian sociable."

Title: Personalia
Item Description: Text reads: "Mr. W. O. Jones, for two years editor of the 'Salem Advertiser,' has just matriculated here. He plays the lead horn in our new band."

Title: Locals
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet company may again be seen tramping over the campus to the musical cadences of yp-yp-yp-yp, interspersed with the no less sonorous 1-2-3-4, 1-2-3-4. The company is in a flourishing condition, and the boys seem to enter into the spirit of soldiery with more zest than ever before. There are several new and valuable acquisitions this term."

Title: Locals [Band Membership]
Item Description: Text reads: "The University Cadet Band is now organized and ready for business. The boys are now prepared to meet any engagement from a dog-fight to a funeral. Professor Hohmann, their instructor, is laboring unceasingly to perfect them in their enterprise. Their officers are as follows: Leader, Will O. Jones; Rec Sec. Wm. c. Gregg; Business Nanager [Manager] D. H. Wheeler; Treasurer, Wm. Hohmann."

Title: Locals [Band Prospects]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadets are now happy. The Band has made sufficient progress to play for them. Now nothing prevents the boys from becoming enthused with martial ardor. We much mistake their natures if the boys do not allow their military enthusiasm to increase. We have a splendid Professor in this department, we have a promising band, and now if the boys do not make an impression before the Regents in June, they have only themselves to blame for it."

Title: Locals
Item Description: Multiple local notices refer to Cadets and band members.  Text reads: "The cadets are making arrangements to attend the State Fair of Omaha...Cadets will be more numerous than ever this year...Will O. Jones, the Leader of the band was unable to be here the first two weeks of the term."

Title: Locals [Sick Members]
Item Description: Text reads: "The bass drum belonging to the Cadet Band has not been heard this term; consequently several students have been taken sick."

Title: Personalia
Item Description: Text reads: "W. O. Jones, leader of the Cadet Band, is again on deck."

Title: Locals [Dissatisfaction with Band Director]
Item Description: Text reads: "If the band instructor which the boys now have does not do his duty, what prevents them from making a change?"

Title: Locals [New Band Director]
Item Description: Text reads: "The U. C. Band has a new teacher. Mr. Everet [Everett] of the City Band now instructs them. It is hoped that this change will prove wise."

Title: Locals [Political Rallies]
Item Description: Text reads: "The U. C. Band has been taking a very active part in the political crisis. Both Republican and Democratic rallies have been enlivened by their presence."

Title: Obituary
Item Description: The U. C. Band leads a funeral procession for Mr. Owen Q. Adams, 28 years old.

Title: Called Home
Item Description: Mrs. Webster, wife of the Cadet commander, passes away. The Cadets escort her remains to the Union Pacific railroad depot.

Title: Locals [Governor's Reception]
Item Description: Text reads: "The University Cadet Band furnished the music at the Governor's reception. The band is gaining a good reputation."

Title: Locals [Garfield's Funeral]
Item Description: The "college band" performs at an event organized in honor of President Garfield's funeral.

Title: Locals [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "There's a Christian in the band but that doesn't make it a Christian band by any means."

Title: The Dormitory
Item Description: The band is practicing three times weekly and can perform multiple pieces of music. The roster and instruments are printed.

Title: Locals [Drum Major]
Item Description: Text reads: "Sergeant D. L. Clark has been chosen drum major of the band. Clark has got music in his soul and business in his eye, and will swing the baton in a way to amaze the natives."

Title: Locals [Chapel Band Room]
Item Description: Text reads: "The gallery of the chapel is turned into a band room and looks very ungodly with the seats littered full of brass horns, band books, and cymbals with a bass drum tucked in behind."

Title: [Untitled]
Item Description: Text reads: "The last new dirge of the Cadet Band would make a cat shed tears. Of course the cat must be a whole-souled feline with an ear for symphony -- and sympathy."

Title: Locals [Singing]
Item Description: Text reads: "Can the Cadet Band sing? Oh, my, yes the Cadet Band can sing as well as play. What does it sing? It sings 'Over the Garden Wall.' "

Title: Locals [New Band Director]
Item Description: Text reads: "Will Jones has resigned the leadership of the Cadet Band and George Hitchcock has been elected to fill the vacancy. The band was never in better condition."

Title: Locals [New Repertoire]
Item Description: Text reads: "Snatches of 'Skids are Out Today,' 'Dancing in the Barn,' 'Boccacio,' 'Turkish Reville,' etc., will be floating around the University during the coming weeks. The band boys have received the music and it is a fine collection, too."

Title: Locals [Roscoe Pound]
Item Description: Roscoe Pound is noted as a faithful "marker" of the Cadet battalian.

Title: Locals [Cadet Member Success]
Item Description: The band's cornet soloist is taking a position with a minstrel group, Haverly's United Mastadon Minstrels.

Title: Locals [Funeral Accompaniment]
Item Description: The band travels to Omaha for the funeral of Col. Watson B. Smith.

Title: [Untitled]
Item Description: D. H. W. Jr. writes in the publication "Trumpet News" about the Cadet Band. The article describes the 12 band member's uniforms as grey with black and gold trim. They are led by Prof. Will O. Jones and have a repertoire of 50 pieces.

Title: Corrrespondence
Item Description: Alumni write to describe their fondness for the band, and their recall of the music they performed.

Title: Locals [Repertoire]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band will soon have 'Over the Garden Wall' arranged, and then we may look for the very worst."

Title: Locals [Webster]
Item Description: Text reads: "The members of the Cadet Battalion are about to make a strong effort to retain their present commander for three years longer. It is the wish of the STUDENT that they may succeed. Lieutenant Webster's place can be filled by no ordinary officer."

Title: Locals [Chapel Rehearsal]
Item Description: A German student disturbed by the Elocution class makes a comparison to the "brass band" which is not allowed to rehearse during the day in the Chapel.

Title: Locals [Spring Rehearsals]
Item Description: The band begins spring rehearsals. Membership is listed.

People: Webster, Isaac T.; Board of Regents
Title: Locals [Webster]
Item Description: The Cadets create a petition to request another detail for Lt. Webster to serve as their leader.

Title: Personalia
Item Description: F. J. Benedict, a "leading musician of the University" joins the band.

Subjects: Military; Concert; Drill; Events & Dances; Repertoire
Title: As Others See Us: Our Charter Day Exercises as Given by the "State Democrat"
Item Description: The "State Democrat" reports that the Cadet Band performed "Sweet Bye and Bye" for part of the Charter Day entertainment.

Title: Locals [Alumnus Visits]
Item Description: Ex-Cadet Band hornist "Tubby," or J. H. Parker, visits Lincoln.

Title: Locals [Crete Rumors]
Item Description: Text reads: "They say...that the band will go to Crete, (Lord help 'em)..."

Title: Locals [New Band Books]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet Band has received a new set of band books, with about one hundred new selections."

Title: Locals [Crete]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band they say, is going to Crete in an astonishing array. Their costumes, it is reported, will also be something peculiar and astonishing to behold."

Title: Spades and Trumps
Item Description: The band takes part in Arbor Day celebrations on campus, playing "industriously for every tree of importance."

Title: Locals [Crete]
Item Description: Text reads: "The trip to Crete is going to be a righ [right] jolly one if the boys can make it so. The band is making strenuous exertions to do something big there and we guess they will succeed."

Title: Locals [Band Serenades]
Item Description: Text reads: "The first band serenade of the spring term occurred Tuesday evening of last week. Mr. Wagner, a newly married friend of the boys, and Lieut. Webster were the afflicted parties. At both places the young gentlemen were handsomely entertained."

Title: Locals [Crete]
Item Description: Text reads: "The big brother of Dan and Myron Wheeler, that is Frank, came up from Plattsmouth to play in the Cadet Band when it went to Crete. He plays baritone and excellently, too. Frank graduates from the Plattsmouth High School in about a week."

Title: Honors to Webster
Item Description: The Cadets present the departing Lt. Webster with a gold headed cane during a reception.

Title: Additional Local [Band Reorganization]
Item Description: Text reads: "The re-organized Cadet Band loometh. We shall have something considerable to say of 'em next issue--if the new bus. man., Frank Wheeler, holds out sufficient inducement."

Title: Miscellaneous Mention [Political Divisions]
Item Description: The author cautions students against viewing University organizations such as the Cadet Band as political, which "mars the true pleasure to be had in those departments..."

Title: [Advertisment]
Item Description: Advertisement reads: "The Cadets make a fine appearance on drill, 'cause they wear boots and shoes, bought at O. W. Webster's."

Title: Campus Canards [Band Membership]
Item Description: The band membership has been selected, list of members follows.

Title: Campus Canards [Request for Info]
Item Description: The Hesperian Student staff asks students to let them know about interesting information they should be covering in the publication. They include an appeal for the band: "If you are a member of the band, bring your horn in and toot it."

Title: Campus Canards [Anti-suffrage March]
Item Description: After the defeat of a vote for women's suffrage in Nebraska, anti-suffrage students form a procession with a casket to "bury the issue." The band accompanied the procession performing a dirge. Despite being attacked by pro-suffrage students, the band and anti-suffragists continue to march up and down O Street playing music to celebrate the defeat of women's suffrage.

Title: On Halloween
Item Description: The Cadet band is mentioned in a poem about Halloween

Title: Campus Canards [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "Scene -- Band playing in Chancellors Office. New student to Soph. 'What is that noise?' Soph. -- 'That, why, that is one of the last year's Faculty meetings.' "

Title: Editorial Notes
Item Description: The Hesperian Student staff note that multiple organizations on campus are demanding more time now that they are becoming established.

Title: Campus Canards [Masons]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet Band played for the Masons last Tuesday. They are called out on all large occasions."

Title: Graduating Exercises
Item Description: The band leads students in a procession to the opera house as part of the graduation exercises.

Title: Campus Canards [New Drum Major]
Item Description: Text reads: "Ben Johuson has been appointed drum major of the band. This is a fitting tribute to his great musical ability."

Title: Campus Canards [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band boys wish to know why it is that whenever they serenade any one of the occupants of the houses in the vicinity always close their windows so tightly"

Title: Campus Canards [Webster Visits]
Item Description: The Cadet Band serenades Lt. Webster upon his stopover in Lincoln during travel.

Title: Campus Canards [Hesperian Student Office for Band Storage]
Item Description: Text reads: "The comps are raising considerable opposition to the use of the office for a receptacle for band instruments, band suits, banjoes and all the paraphernalia of music. If the band cannot keep their insignia in their own room, we see no reason why they should inflict the STUDENT office with their scattered remains."

Title: Editorial Notes [Arbor Day Cancelled]
Item Description: As the founder of Arbor Day, J. Sterling Morton, cannot visit campus, there will not be a celebration. If there had been, the band would have performed.

Title: Campus Canards [Decoration Day]
Item Description: The Cadet Band takes part in the Decoration Day procession, marching to 28th St and then to the Cemetery. The Hesperian Student notes: "The cadets and their band were highly complimented with respect to discipline and music. However, the bass drummer should remember that a drum head can not stand a blow of over 1000 lbs. violence, and that bayonets are not just the things for drum sticks."

Title: Campus Canards [New Director]
Item Description: Text reads: "We understand that the Band boys have obtained the services of Prof. Weber, of the University, as their leader and instructor. Besides being an able pianist the Professor is an unusually fine violinist and coronetist."

Title: Campus Canards [Wedding]
Item Description: The Cadet Band serenades a recently married couple and is mistaken for the city band.

Title: Campus Canards [Skating Rink Employment]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band boys have been offered a position in the roller skating rink. If they accept they will play three evenings a week. This speaks well for our band and it is with pleasure that we see them coming to the front so that they may be heard."

Title: Campus Canards [Building Wishlist]
Item Description: The Hesperian Student wishes that the Regents would plan on a building specifically for the band "in the farthest corner of the college farm."

Title: Campus Canards [Roster]
Item Description: The roster of the band is printed, including new band director Easterday

Title: Campus Canards [Skating Rink]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet Band still holds the fort at the skating rink"

Title: Campus Canards [New Instructor]
Item Description: Text reads: "Our Cadet Band is wide awake this term and seem bent on doing their level best. They are to be congratulated upon having secured the services of Prof. Easterday as their instructor. The band is composed of good material, and it is becoming well developed under the Professor's able management."

Title: Campus Canards [Skating Rink Race]
Item Description: The Cadet Band, performing in the gallery, is witness to a roller skating rink race.

Title: They Say [Miscellaneous]
Item Description: The Cadet Band is mentioned three times in the "They Say" column, with humorous entries about a potential name change and possible concerts. The column also notes that the Cadet Band performed for the Homeopathic School of Medicine's commencement without asking for money.

Title: The Migration of the Medics
Item Description: The Cadet Band performs at the commencement ceremony for the Allopathic / Homeopathic School of Medicine, despite terrible weather.

Title: Campus Canards [Rehearsal]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Band boys are rehearsing assiduously these days and when spring-time comes will undoubtedly be in condition to hold the gbouquet. Their music is of a higher grade than ever before used in the University."

Title: Campus Canards [Roscoe Pound]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet Band claims the smallest drum major in the country. Roscoe Pound is the young gentleman who has been elevated to the position, and although he can scarcely see over the bass drum he is better versed in military tactics than the best six-footer in the ranks."

Title: Campus Canards [Easterday Mentioned]
Item Description: Cadet Band director Easterday directs an orchestra concert, and is credited as the instructor of the Cadet Band, specifically.

Title: Drift [Milford Encampment]
Item Description: The article jokes that mosquitos may "finish the band" during the Cadet's encampment in Milford.

Title: The Annual
Item Description: The Cadets and Brass Band will be included in the coming College Annual publication.

People: Dudley, Edgar S.; Webster, Isaac T.
Title: Milford Encampment
Item Description: A birds-eye view of the Cadet encampment in Milford, NE, which includes "streets" named after Webster and Dudley, previous commanders of the Cadets.

Title: Campus Canards [Milford Encampment]
Item Description: The Cadets, including the band, embark on their trip to Milford, NE for an encampment.

Title: Drift [Praise for Band]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet Band is now the best band in the city. The University is proud of its musical students. Once the band was mobbed and tarred every night. That is all over now. The citizens of Lincoln are thankful; so are the band boys. Practice makes perfect, and the band must have had practice. This is intended as a hint that it is perfect."

Title: Drift [Milford Encampment]
Item Description: The Cadets are preparing for their encampment in Milford with a large number of provisions. Neighbors are warned to guard their livestock from Cadets who may leave camp despite instructions to remain in place.

Title: Drift [Praise for Easterday]
Item Description: Professor David F. Easterday is praised for his work with musical groups on campus, including the Cadet band.

Title: Campus Canards [New Band Room]
Item Description: Text reads: "The fitting up of one of the rooms on the fourth floor for the use of the band boys is certainly an improvement upon the old order of things, and one for which the boys are truly thanksful; while on the other hand those not connected with them are denouncing most bitterly the English language as it is incapable of describing or even making known their breadths, lengths, and depths of thankfulness. We rejoice that the change is taken so kindly by all."

Title: Editorial Notes [New Band Room]
Item Description: Prior to this year, the band has not had a dedicated room for rehearsal and storage. However, this year they have a room on the "fourth floor" with risers, which is maximizing rehearsal time by allowing for quick locating of music and seats.

Title: Campus Canards [Dress Parade and Uniform Ad]
Item Description: The Hesperian Student makes note of the dress-parade appearance of the Cadets and band. Additionally, there is a notice about "cadet suits and caps at T. Ewing & Co's clothing house," an advertisement which frequently runs in the student paper.

Title: Campus Canards [Club rally]
Item Description: The Cadet Band performs for the University Blaine and Logan club, which includes a parade to the corner of Government square. James G. Blaine and John A. Logan ran for President and Vice President of the United States against Grover Cleveland in 1884.

Title: Campus Canards [Employment for Political Campaigns]
Item Description: Text reads: "The campaign brought out the Cadet Band at several political blow-outs during the past few weeks. Verily, verily it brings chink into the boys' pockets but woe unto the man so unfortunate as to be a spectator."

Title: Campus Canards [Presidential Election Results]
Item Description: The Cadet Band paraded through Lincoln playing a "dirge" to indicate their displeasure with the presidential election results of Cleveland. The article notes they "showed their elasticity of conscience" by later appearing to perform celebratory music for Cleveland.

Title: Campus Canards [Criticism of Band and Election Results]
Item Description: The author criticizes the band's funerial performance on the election of Grover Cleveland, especially as the election results were not yet final.

Title: Campus Canards [New Orleans]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet Band wants to go to New Orleans but Canaday won't consent."

Title: Campus Canards [Beatrice Encampment]
Item Description: The Cadets are preparing for encampment in Beatrice.

Title: Commencement
Item Description: The Cadet Band takes part in the 14th annual Commcement ceremony. A parade formed at the University building, then traveled down 11th to the Opera House.

Title: Commencement
Item Description: The Cadet Band performs at the Opera House during the Commencement ceremony

Title: Campus Canards [Saengerfest]
Item Description: Text reads: "The small but noisy remnant of the Cadet Band that remains in the city has been engaged to assist our German brethren in their Saengerfest."

Title: Campus Canards [Dress Parade]
Item Description: Text reads: "The first dress parade of the term took place last Friday afternoon on the campus. Co. D. of the State Militia, under command of Captain Hotchkiss participated in the parade. The Cadet Band furnished music for the occasion."

Title: Campus Canards [Band Reorganization]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet band has been re-organized this year. Seven of the old band members resigned on account of having served their time, and new men fill their places. Prof. Easterday instructs them and we shall doubtless have a good band before next Commencement."

Title: Campus Canards [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band is improving in spite of the fact that Breech blows an alto."

Title: Mayer Bros Advertisement
Item Description: Mayer Bros advertisement for Cadet uniforms and caps. "See Them."

Title: Direct Pointers [Metal Polish]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band has invested $3.00 in a gallon of wonderful metal polish. The instruments cannot be looked at with the naked eye hereafter."

Title: Campus Canards [Palladian Society]
Item Description: Text reads: "It is rumored that the members of the University Band who inflicted such torture upon the literary societies not long since, were treated in the Palladian Society as they deserved. 'Tis said they were led out by the ear."

Title: Heard in the Halls [New Band Members]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band begins the year with more flattering prospects than ever before since its organization. The greater part of the old members are back, and besides there are some three or four new men who are experienced players. Indeed the band is now in as good trim as at the close of last year, and that is saying a good deal for the boys."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Knights of Pythias]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band accompanied the Knights of Pythias to Beatrice June 3rd. They tell of a glorious time, and everything they wanted to eat."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Open Air Concerts]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band has given two open air concerts at the band stand on Government square, the last one being on June 5th. The boys have received many compliments on their playing, both from individuals and from the press."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Odd Fellows' Celebration]
Item Description: The Cadet Band performs in Omaha at the Odd Fellows' Celebration. The article notes "the sixteen members of the band, with their new uniforms presented quite a fine appearance."

Title: Campus Canards [New Uniforms]
Item Description: The Board of Regents approves new Cadet Band uniforms and abolishes drill during winter term.

Title: Direct Pointers [New Uniforms]
Item Description: The band has been provided with $175 for new uniforms. The description of the uniform is: "A close-fitting blue blouse, gold braided, will be used, with ordinary dark pants and a neat low cap. The effect will be much better than with the grey 'swallow tails' that have been in use for the past five years."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Large Band]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band has an unusually large membership this term. W. S. Perrin, Drum Major, promises to surprise the gaping crowd when he appears again with his charge."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Group Photos]
Item Description: Text reads: "A photographer came up Friday of last week and 'shot at' the artillery departments, dress parade, and the band in the most approved manner. None of the boys fainted and we begin to believe the cadets are not so chicken-hearted as they have been represented."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Essay Reading]
Item Description: The Cadet Band is praised for their performance at an essay reading by Lt. Dudley on "The Necessity of Closer Relations Between the Army and the People"

People: Bessey, Charles Edwin; Wheeler, Frank L.
Title: Arbor Day
Item Description: The Cadet Band accompanies the Junior class on their tree planting mission. The group buries a time capsule under their tree. A later page mentions that though the Cadet Band's music may be forgotten in the future, the tree will still stand. The band performs "Hail Columbia."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Band Member's Illness]
Item Description: Frank Wheeler, the band's business manager, is sickened with typhoid fever.

Title: Heard in the Halls [Band Member's Death]
Item Description: Frank L. Wheeler, senior in the Cadet Band, has died. He was business manager of the band and remembered favorably by students and instructors alike. The Cadet Band escorted his family from the residence where Wheeler died to the train station bound for his hometown of Plattsmouth.

Title: Our Prize Contest
Item Description: At least one band member, Frank Wheeler, has a strong submission for the university song contest.

Title: Advertisement
Item Description: Advertisement for "Cadet Suits, Indigo Blue $8.00 to $11.50 at Mayer Bros. 10th St. Clothiers"

Title: Heard in the Halls [Trip to Omaha]
Item Description: Text reads: "Harry Clark accompanied the band to Omaha for the purpose of gathering materials for a new lecture to be entitled 'Lights and Shadows of a Great City.' "

Title: Heard in the Halls [Milford Encampment]
Item Description: The Cadets and band encamp in Milford, NE.

Title: Miscellany [Band Room]
Item Description: The "band room" is mentioned in passing

Title: Heard in the Halls [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band is still increasing. It now numbers something less than 81."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Band Room Swap]
Item Description: Text reads: "Those who frequent the lower floor very much have noticed a change which considerably improves the atmosphere thereabouts -- that of the removal of the medical lecture room to the fourth floor. The band have exchanged places with them and now the hum of the student in recitation is mingled with the soft and gentle music of the cadet band."

Title: Heard in the Halls [Band Room Swap Back]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band is disgusted with their trade of rooms made during the winter and take advantage of the absence of the Meds [medical students] to trade back."

Title: Hall Happenings [Field Day]
Item Description: The Field Day program is published, which includes multiple pieces performed by the Cadet Band, as well as a parade. Additionally, games and contests such as a sack race, wrestling, and "screaming match" will be held.

Title: Hall Happenings [Field Day Joke]
Item Description:
Text reads: "Upon request of the management of the cadet band we announce that a NEW selection will be rendered at dress parade next Friday afternoon. This is done to allow preparation for the unusual nervous shock which will undoubtably follow such an unprecedented occurence.
LATER.-- We are informed that the above announcement is a vile slander. Some villain, apparently intended to perpetrate a cruel joke."

Title: Editorial Notes [Field Day]
Item Description: The Hesperian Student editors is enthusiastic about the concept of a Field Day, and wonders if the baseball fields may be reserved, as the Cadets and band are willing to take part in the plan.

Title: Field Day
Item Description: The results of Field Day are published, and the band is noted as having "discoursed delicious(?) music for a short time..."

Title: Commencement Day
Item Description: The band leads a procession to the Opera House for the Commencement Day address.

Title: Commencement Notes
Item Description: Text reads: "The procession, headed by the band, made a gorgeous appearance. The clerks in the stores turned out and stared as if it was a ten cent circus."

People: Dudley, Edgar S.; Manatt, Irving J.
Title: Stray Pick-ups [Uniform Loan Deception]
Item Description: Text reads: "A committee of the K. P.'s [Knights of Pythias] asked the Chancellor and the Steward for the loan of the Cadet Band uniforms to wear to Omaha last week and were referred by both these gentlemen to Lieut. Dudley. They went to him and represented that the Chancellor and Steward had both given their consent so he let the uniforms go without further consideration. This will not occur again."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Band Roster]
Item Description: The roster of the 1887-1888 cadet band is published.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "When the adjutant commanded 'sound off' the band sounded way off -- Sergeant."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Escorting Governor]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadets and the cadet band assisted in escorting the governor from the depot to the state house. Many of the cadets did not take part, however, as they had not yet procured their uniforms or been sufficiently drilled."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Odd Fellows]
Item Description: Text reads: "The University cadet band furnished music for the Odd Fellows on the 20th ult."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Band Improvement]
Item Description: The article compliments the band's efforts, as many of the new members had "never played before this term, and the first time they appeared it would have been hard to tell when they commenced or quit playing had it not been for the base [bass] drum..." but they are improving quickly.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [New Uniforms]
Item Description: Text reads: "The long expected band uniforms have arrived and henceforth all the musicians will resemble each other. The drum major's habiliments surpass in grandeur and gaiety anything we ever saw outside of a circus."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Drummer]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet Band has been having a hard time to find a drummer. We understand that Males has at last been initiated into that office, and the band is now complete."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "Bert Wheeler.-- (at band practice) 'It is now 5 o'clock, professor, and I should like to be excused.' Prof. E [Easterday] 'Be excused? Why, is she waiting for you?' Yes, she was waiting at the foot of the stairs."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke Followup]
Item Description:
Text reads: "Mr. Bert Wheeler has been in Omaha for the last two weeks enjoying his easter vacation. He reports that the girl is still waiting at the foot of the stairs--H.S. Register.
The above may be an item of interest to the girl of the U. of N. who seems to have unconsciously fallen into the habit of her Omaha sister..."  The column goes on to describe the new co-ed cadets [Company D].

Title: Advertisement
Item Description: An advertisement in The Hesperian Student foband director D. F. Easterday's services as an "instructor in music."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Dress Parade]
Item Description: Text reads: "The first dress parade of the term occurred Friday. As a whole it was bad, very bad. The captains were mostly green and the men ditto. The band tooted its piece and walked its walk in style but they differed as to quitting."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Battalion Size]
Item Description: Text reads: "The battalion this year is composed of four companies and numbers fully 100 menf [men] exclusive of band and officers."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Museum]
Item Description: The band is mentioned in a blurb about the location of Mr. Bruner's offices from the museum to the west attic while Nebraska Hall is being finished.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Band for Hire]
Item Description: The band's officers are published and the reader is urged: "The boys are prepared to give music, etc. on short notice. All wishing first class music at a reasonable price please apply."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Band Members' Wealth]
Item Description: Text reads: "The University band is rolling in wealth. During the campaign they played for the prohibitionists on November 6, and in the republican jubilee."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Drum Major Staff]
Item Description: Text reads: "Graham now bears the spheretopped staff with which the band is beaten into subjection. Just at present he wears an ornament new to the office. He says he got it 'down town' but that leaves a good deal to be imagined."

Title: Sketches [Band of Youths]
Item Description: This sketch describes the chagrine of a Cadet Officer who is followed around town by an enthusiastic band of children who have taken it upon themselves to accompany his journey.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "The plastering in the Union hall is down again. Cause, the band."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Summer Employment]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band boys have received a very remunerative position at a summer resort in the Catskills for next summer. We guess there won't be any cats left next fall."

Subjects: Uniform & Equipment; Fundraising & Finance; Other Band
Title: Stray Pick-ups [New Instrument Possibility]
Item Description: Text reads: "It is rumored that the Lincoln Military band wish to sell their instruments. This would be an excellent opportunity for the regents to get a new set of instruments for the cadet band. They are sadly in need of such a set."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Crete]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Mammoth University Cadet Band and the far-famed pie worshippers of the lab. will go to Crete, April 12."

Title: Editorial Notes [State of Instruments]
Item Description: The Hesperian Student publishes a "protest"  of the condition of the Cadet Band's instruments, which are holding back the band's quality. "There is no reason why the U. of N. cannot have as good an amateur band as there is in the state if the cadets had the proper instruments."

Title: Editorial Notes [Crete]
Item Description: The state oratorical contest is to be held in Crete and all students are urged to attend. "Take the co-eds to Crete. If they cannot cheer, they will be excellent mascots. Let the cadet band go to Crete. Leave dirges and funeral marches behind. Let the University be in full force at Crete, and prove that it has an orator whom it is proud to cheer and support."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Rollerskating]
Item Description: The band is performing three nights a week at the skating rink. "They will derive practical as well as pecuniary benefits from the engagement."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "The Cadet Band would go well with the salvation army."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Governor's Luncheon]
Item Description: Text reads: "The University Cadet band rendered some very nice music at the reception at the capitol Tuesday evening. Governor Thayer showed his appreciation by the delicious luncheon tendered the members."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Spring Recess]
Item Description: Text reads: "A number of the 'yaps' spent the recess in town, and employed a part of their time recuperating their wind power in anticipation of April 12. The same remark is also applicable to a part of the cadet band."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Band Wealth and City Elections]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band is fast becoming the wealthiest organization in the University. Besides playing regularly at the skating rink, they are in their harvest -- the city elections. They have several engagements with aspiring politicians this week."

Title: The Contest at Crete
Item Description: The band travels to Crete for a Doane v NU baseball game and oratory contest.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke]
Item Description: The Hesperian Student jokes that audience members sought medical attention after hearing a "spasmodic rendering" of the piece "Pem-Ta-Ta- Overture."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Odd Fellows]
Item Description: Text reads: "The University cadet band accompanied the Odd Fellows to Beatrice, Friday."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke]
Item Description: The Hesperian Student publishes several jokes about embarrassing a band member in front of women, and comparing a women's ensemble against the men's.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Surprise Birthday Serenade]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band boys with their co-eds spent a very favorable evening last Saturday. They met at the Uni with the apparent intention of going out on a serenade, and promenaded out to Eighteenth and L to the accompanient [accompaniment] of the Major drum, before Males thought to remember that it was the occasion of his twenty-first birthday and to conclude that he was marching the band out to serenade himself. They dispersed early Sunday morning. Bryan receives credit for neatly working up the surprise."

Title: Our Military Day
Item Description: The Cadets take part in competitive drills. Due to a rain delay, the band entertains the crowd gathered in the Armory.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Military Day Preparation]
Item Description: Multiple blurbs are related to the band and Cadets preparation for the upcoming Military Day / competitive drill.

Title: Recent Happenings [Summer Employment]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band will keep up their organization through the summer and try to rake in the shekels."

Title: Commencement Exercises
Item Description: The band performs for the 18th annual commencement. See also: page 15.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band sounds much better from a great distance than at short range. Won't they go out of town during dress parade?"

Title: Stray Pick-ups [New Baritone]
Item Description: Text reads: "The instruments of the band have been increased in number and quality by the purchase of a new $40 baritone horne. O. G. Miller operates the new instrument."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Serenading Cows]
Item Description: Text reads: "On the last Friday the band serenaded the cows and railroad tracks of North Lincoln. They complain that the lack of beauty in their surroundings out there does not inspire them to emit entrancing strains of harmony."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Band Membership]
Item Description: The list of new band members and instruments is published.

Title: Miscellany [Encampment Memories]
Item Description: Lt. Dudley's visit to Lincoln brings back fond memories of the encampment in Wymore. The band is briefly mentioned.

Title: A Dozen Decades Hence
Item Description: A poem mentions the band may still be learning new music in June "a dozen decades hence."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Easterday Illness]
Item Description: Text reads: "Professor D. F. Easterday has been quite sick for two weeks, and the band has been worrying along without an instructor. We are glad to notice that he was back at his post again this week."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [George Washington's Birthday]
Item Description: Text reads: "On Friday afternoon, Feb. 21, the cadet band played at the celebration of George Washington's birthday by the students of the C street public school. After playing several pieces in the different rooms they were royally entertained with refreshments by the teachers, and came away unanimously voting them the best lot of schoolma'ms in the city."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Charter Day]
Item Description: The band performs for Charter Day.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [George Washington's Birthday]
Item Description: Text reads: "The university cadet band, and the old eagle, the one that has been in the museum for some time, helped the C street school celebrate Washington's birth day."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Governor's Reception]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band played for the governor's reception last Wednesday evening. After reception the boys were feasted in such a royal fashion that they wish receptions would come oftener."

Title: Notes [Extreme Cold]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band had considerable trouble in furnishing music owing to the cold freezing the instruments."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: "The university cadet band is not a fraternity organization for it plays 'Barb' quickstep."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [St. Patrick's Day]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band accompanied the ancient order of Hibernians to the B. M. depot while on their way to Tecumseh to celebrate St. Patrick's Day"

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Dress Parade]
Item Description: Text reads: "Notwithstanding the inclement weather, Lieutenant Griffith says that he never saw the companies execute a better manual than at the last dress parade. He is also well pleased with the band, which is in excellent condition after its several changes last fall. The battalion commences wiht the spring term under most promising circumstances, and will doubtless do able work during the term."

Title: Wesleyan Wins. Our Own Mr. Fogarty a Close Second
Item Description: The band greets contestants arriving for the state oratorical contest. After leading a delegation of students to meet the incoming teams at the Elkhorn and B & M depots, the band paraded up P to 11th Street, and then to the university.

Title: Miscellany: Hastings Encampment
Item Description: Nearly 100 Cadets will be making their encampment in Hastings, NE.

Title: Camp Laird
Item Description: A description of the Cadets' encampment in Hastings, NE, which was not entirely pleasant.

Title: Camp Laird: Notes
Item Description: In a section regarding the recent experience of the Cadets in Hastings, NE, the text reads: "The ladies' band is all right; at least a few of the members of our band seemed to think so."

Title: Editorial Notes [Drill Grounds]
Item Description: The editors criticize the appearance of campus and comment that the drill grounds are too small for the cadet battalion.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Congressional Debate]
Item Description: The band attends a debate in support of William Jennings Bryan against incumbent William James Connell in the 1890s 1st congressional district's race.

Title: Editorial Notes [YMCA Football Match]
Item Description: It is hoped that the NU football team will accept a challenge by the Omaha Y.M.C.A., and that that band will travel to the game to support the team.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Cadet Numbers]
Item Description: Text reads: "Including the band boys, there are 135 men drilling this term, an increase of ten men over last winter."

People: Griffith, T. W.; Thayer, John Milton
Title: Stray Pick-ups [Military Service]
Item Description: The cadets volunteer for military service but it seems unlikely they will be called up.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Concert]
Item Description: Text reads: "Wednesday evening, the 14th, the U. of N. band played a selection or two of very fine music in the hall on the third floor of the main building. The music went right to the toes of some of the audience. The Unions have a good opinion of the band boys and of their musical ability."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Clothier Concert]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band played for Semmons, the clothier, the forenoon of Saturday, January 24."

Title: Athletics [Doane Football]
Item Description: The band waits several hours at the train depot for the football team to return from Doane. They parade through the town to Chancellor Bessey's but fail to wake him up to celebrate.

Title: Oratorical Convention
Item Description: The band leads a parade from the university to the train depot, where it performs several selections, before returning to the university for the oratorical convention.

Title: Exchange [Oratorical Convention Hurt Feelings]
Item Description: The Gates Exchange criticizes multiple aspects of how the State Oratorical Convention was run, and also criticizes that there was not a reception committee at the train depot to meet them. The Hesperian promises that, had Gates' itinerary been known, the band would have met them "in royal style."

Title: Advertisement [Uniform]
Item Description: An advertisement for Wanamaker & Brown promises that cadets suits are their specialty.

People: Bessey, Charles Edwin; Griffith, T. W.
Title: A Mighty Night of Fun and Frolic
Item Description: The band takes part in a large procession through Lincoln which the paper notes will "long be remembered." The procession stops at hotels, the offices of the Journal, and the residences of many individuals. Fireworks are lit at the end of speeches.

Title: Mockett Wins the Bicycle Race
Item Description: The band is mentioned as performing during a bicycle contest.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [High School Concert]
Item Description: Text reads: "The univeristy band made music for the high school, Arbor Day."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Accident at the Concert]
Item Description: Text reads: "They were at the head of the stairs coming form the cadet band concert. She tripped and rolled clear to the bottom. He took from the doctor a solemn oath not to give it away."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Concert in Fairbury]
Item Description: The Journal reports that the recent band concert was excellent and that they will be repeating the performance in Fairbury during the cadet encampment. During the previous concert, the band director, Easterday, was presented with the gift of a baton.

Title: The Cadet Encampment
Item Description: The cadets stop in Crete on the way to Fairbury and the band performs. After arriving in Fairbury, the band and cadets process with the rest of the town to the camp.  On Saturday the band gives a concert.

Title: Twentieth Annual Commencement
Item Description: The band performs several selections for the commencement

Title: Among the Professors [Pershing Assigned]
Item Description: Text reads: "J. J. Pershing, 2nd lieutenant 6th cavalry, who takes charge of the military department, is a graduate from West Point. If appearances are not very deceptive, he will prove very popular with the cadets. He is the brother of the Misses May and Grace Pershing who were students here three years ago."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Moving Gymnasium Time]
Item Description: The women's physical training class is having trouble finding space for class between the cadet battalion and the band's rehearsals occuping the same rooms.

Title: How They Spent Vacation
Item Description: Text reads: "Pizey studied law, played in the band, and stayed at Brown's restaurant."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Battalion Numbers]
Item Description: Text reads: "There are now 185 cadets registered in the battalion."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [New Instruments]
Item Description: Text reads: "The cadet band made their initial appearance on the street with the new instruments, the 22nd ult. They spent nearly the entire day playing for the I. O. O. F. [Odd Fellows] organization."

Title: Military Department [Exercises]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band boys seem to think that they are not cut out for setting up exercises and take to the work about like a hen to water."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Cadet Uniforms]
Item Description: Multiple blurbs mention new uniforms which have been ordered for the Cadets from Cincinnatti, Ohio.

Title: Stray Pick-ups
Item Description: Text reads: "And the band played 'thirty two to nothing.' "

Title: Those Champions at Doane
Item Description: The band waits three cold hours at the train depot waiting for the football team to return victorious.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [May Concerts]
Item Description: Text reads: "We are glad to know that arrangements are being made whereby the cadet band will play each evening during May and the early part of June in the city. The cadet band is in excellent condition and has fifteen men well drilled by Professor Easterday. They also have a large repertoire of the latest popular music. The band is in better condition than it has ever been in the past."

Title: Editorial Notes [Drill Requirement Changes]
Item Description: The editors complain of "dictatorial orders" requiring male students to drill for nine consecutive terms and that they shall no longer choose their own uniform supplier. The editors worry that not all students will be able to afford the expenses of attending the university, nor want to commit to so many years of military education.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [World's Fair Photograph]
Item Description: Text reads: "Mr. Howard F. Pierson, of the Capital Studio, (late Le Grande) requests that all students wearing cadet uniforms call for a negative to be used in a group of all students, which will be exhibited at the world's fair. All other students call also. Come as early as possible."

Title: Stray Pick-ups [Cadence Marker]
Item Description: Text reads: "The lieutenant now has an instrument to mark the cadence while the cadets are executing the manual of arms. This will train each cadet to execute the different commands at the proper time and will improve the appearance of the battalion by giving it a uniformity of movement."

Title: Editorial Notes [Drill Competition]
Item Description: The editors share their eagerness to send only those cadets fitting certain qualities of drill competence and physical stature to a drill competition in Omaha.

Title: Alumni and Former Students [Drill and Uniform Changes]
Item Description: Clement Chase (class of 1883) supports the military department's changes to drill and uniform requirements in a lengthy article to the Hesperian. "I am rather pleased than otherwise to ascertain that hereafter no cadet will be allowed to wear any part of his uniform when not on duty unless he wears the whole. To my mind, nothing looks seedier than to see a neat blue jacket with brownish or yellowish or even black trousers; or a little cadet cap on the head of a man the rest of whose dress does not carry out the military idea."

Title: The State Contest at Crete
Item Description: The band performs while the judges decide the outcome of an oratorical contest. The bottom of the page contains more notes about the band cheer and serenading activity.

Title: Stray Pick-ups [New Band Uniforms]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band has received some new uniforms. Although they are not showy, they are neat and are a great improvement over the old uniforms."

Title: New Rules and Regulations for the Military Department Next Year
Item Description: Parody guidelines are published in The Hesperian which include regulations such as "No cadet shall wear his coat and cap without his pantaloons" and the inclusion in the US constitution of slavery and involuntary servitude as punishment for those who enroll at the University of Nebraska.

Title: Locals [Band Membership]
Item Description: Text reads: "The band started out this year with twenty-four playing members. Five or six more are waiting to join as soon as instruments can be provided. Professor Easterday will wield the baton and make it the best and largest band ever organized by the university."

Title: Exchange [Drum Corps Proposal]
Item Description: As a solution to the lack of instruments, this author suggests that perhaps students should organize a drum corps to finance the purchase of enough instruments.

Title: Locals [Joke]
Item Description: Text reads: " 'No', said the rustic, watching the awkward squads and finally spying Will Westerman 'setting up' the band, 'I believe those must be the incurables.' "

Subjects: Uniform & Equipment; Concert; Meetings & Membership; Repertoire
Title: Locals [Praise for Band]
Item Description: Easterday and the 30 member cadet band are praised. They will soon be performing music "worthy of the brass."

People: Pershing, John J. (John Joseph); Canfield, James H.
Title: Locals [Pershing Surprise Party - Maiden Prize]
Item Description: To celebrate their success at the drill competition in Omaha and the award of the Maiden Prize, a surprise party is thrown for Lieutenant Pershing. The former captain of Company A presents Pershing with a sabre inscribed with his name and the details of the competition.

Title: The Awkward Squad
Item Description: A lengthy essay about an "awkard squad" of new students unfamiliar with drill touches briefly on the concept of a band of new members.

Title: Honorary Band Frat Initiates New Men
Item Description: The twenty-one new members of the ROTC band inducted into Gamma Lambda are listed, and the ceremony is briefly described.

Title: Grant Memorial Will be Scene of First Rally
Item Description: The ROTC band will lead a parade from the armory to the Lincoln hotel, where the Texas A&M football team and coaches are staying. The band will also meet Texas A&M fans at the train station and parade through downtown to the Colliseum.

Title: Tour, Bonfire Rally Planned for Texans
Item Description: The ROTC band will meet Texas Aggie fans at the train station, and, with the Texas A&M band, will parade through downtown.

People: Schulte, Henry; Quick, W. T.; Bible, Dana X.
Title: 3,000 Ralliers Welcome Texas Friday Evening
Item Description: The band performs at a two-hour rally and leads a parade from the armory to the Lincoln Hotel, where a rally continued with the Texas A&M band and supporters. A parade with the Corn Cobs and Tassels returned to campus.

Title: Curtis, Bible are Headliners
Item Description: Leo Beck's orchestra will play at a rally for the Pitt football game, and jazz band directed by Harlan Easton will perform new Cornhusker pep song by Joyce Ayres. The marching band will parade from Temple to Memorial Hall.

Subjects: Parade; Cheer & Pep; Sports; Pregame & Halftime; Repertoire
Title: Varied Stunts Put on Between Halves
Item Description: The band performs before the Pitt-Nebraska football game and during halftime. Another article on the page describes the pep rally and parade held for the game as well as the new song, "Fight, Husker Varsity."

Title: Husker Send Off Rally Called at 4 P.M. Thursday
Item Description: Following a rally on the drill field, the marching band will lead a parade to see the football team off at the Burlington depot. The football team travels to Lawrence, Kansas to play against the Univerity of Kansas Jayhawks.

Title: KU Tickets Selling Out Fast
Item Description: About 65 band members, along with Corn Cobs and Tassels will take the train to the Nebraska-Kansas football game in Lawrence, Kansas.

Title: Innocents Plan Pre-Game Rally to Greet K.U.
Item Description: The band will play at a parade and rally before the basketball game against Kansas.

Title: Last Band Concert is Set for Tonight
Item Description: The band wil play the season's last concert at the Coliseum.

Title: Plans Complete for Pep Show in the Stadium Tonight
Item Description: The band will lead a parade from Temple to a rally in the stadium. Dads will be honored at the Iowa-Nebraska football game.

Title: Burnett Orders Military Parade for Wednesday
Item Description: ROTC cadets will parade in Armistice Day celebration.
